awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2019:  Population genomics of elevational range limits in Andean birds
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2019, Research Using Biological Collections. The fellowship supports research and training of the fellow that will utilize biological collections in innovative ways. All species occur within a limited area known as their geographic range. Range limits can form without an obvious physical barrier because competition with other species prevents further expansion, because they are unable to adapt to a new environment, or because there are too few individuals of the same species to reproduce effectively. Many tropical organisms have narrow elevational ranges, meaning they occur only for a short vertical distance on continuous mountain slopes. This allows many species to coexist in a small area, and is part of why the tropics have so many species. However, we know relatively little about what determines elevational ranges in the tropics. The fellow will use DNA sequence data from extensive museum collections of Andean birds to understand the role of evolutionary and ecological processes in forming range limits. By understanding how these processes interact, we can better predict how species will respond to human induced environmental change. This has broad implications for biodiversity conservation and human health as endangered species and new diseases experience a warming world. 

The fellow will evaluate alternate hypotheses for species range limits by comparing the spatial distribution of genetic variation of tropical songbird species that have either narrow (<1500 m) or broad (>3000 m) elevational ranges. Using dense geographic sampling in extant biological collections from the Peruvian Andes, he will generate genome-wide DNA sequence data from across the full elevational ranges of 8 phylogenetically independent lineages. Each lineage will contain both elevational specialist and elevational generalist species. He will first use these data to identify the evolutionary and ecological processes that determine elevational ranges in Andean birds. Comparing observed patterns with predictions validated by simulations, he will evaluate the relative contribution of decreasing effective population size, biotic interactions, and migration from maladapted populations to the formation of equilibrium range limits. He will then test whether functional variation in hemoglobin is a prerequisite for elevational range expansion, and characterize whether adaptive variants have undergone hard or soft selective sweeps. During his postdoctoral research, the fellow will undergo training in museum curation and biodiversity informatics, advanced statistical genomics, and functional genetics. The research will be based at University of New Mexico, a majority-minority R1 institution, where the fellow will serve as a mentor in a training program for underrepresented students interested in research careers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Why do species occur where they do? Understanding the factors shaping species ranges is a major goal in the field of evolutionary ecology. It is challenging as it is difficult to study in a laboratory, involves assessing the importance of multiple variables, and requires making sense of variation across space, time, and the tree of life. Because they are easily observed, birds have long been a focus of species range research. Tropical bird species are known for their unusually narrow elevational ranges, which scientists have hypothesized are shaped by adaptation to temperature or altitude, competition with other species, or patchy food availability. This project evaluated alternate hypotheses for elevational range limits across a diverse group of bird species found in the Peruvian Andes. Drawing on data associated with specimens from extant biological collections, it assessed the relationship between genetic and physiological variation and elevational range characteristics. 

The project found that genomic regions associated with respiratory traits were correlated with elevation in a family of bird species that repeatedly colonized high mountain regions, indicating adaptation to reduced oxygen availability plays a role in determining high elevation occupancy. Physiological traits associated with blood oxygen-carrying capacity--like blood hemoglobin concentration--were also related to elevation, both within and among species. This suggests that genetic adaptation does not alter a fundamental relationship between a trait relevant to fitness and the environment, though further analysis found that the mechanism responsible for this relationship varies and may be determined by genetics. Species with broad elevational ranges showed a greater degree of sensitivity to elevation in blood trait values, indicating increased acclimatization ability may be important for these rare elevational 'generalists.' At any given location, the total amount of blood trait variation present was related to elevation and how far individual birds were from the upper or lower edge of their distribution, suggesting natural selection on respiratory physiology may contribute to range limit formation. Taken together, these findings are evidence that elevational ranges are jointly influenced by genomics, physiology, and oxygen availability, and likely contribute to their relative stability (or 'conservation') over evolutionary time. Additionally, they suggest tropical mountain birds may be unable to quickly respond to climate change.

The project also helped the fellow meet several important training and professional development goals, including networking with scientists with complementary areas of research, learning how to analyze physiological and functional genomic data, developing expertise in advanced statistical models, and building biodiversity informatics and museum curation skills. This experience will be invaluable in his career as a PI at a research university. He further participated in research, training, and outreach activities as a member of the diverse scientific community at the University of New Mexico, a majority-minority R1 institution. As a mentor, he helped graduate students with data analysis, scientific presentation, grant applications, and manuscript preparation; one is now a postdoctoral researcher with fellowship support. Findings were disseminated through scientific publications, conference presentations, university seminars, and natural history museum open house events. This work highlights the value of biological collections in providing multiple types of georeferenced data for use in species distribution research.
